verses.text: My son, keep my words and treasure my commandments within you.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the importance of internalizing wisdom, echoing similar advice on hiding God's word in the heart. The act of 'treasuring' aligns with spiritual disciplines and meditative prayer.

verses.text: Keep my commandments and live; guard my teaching as the apple of your eye.
verses.comment: The expression 'apple of your eye' shows the preciousness of God's instruction. Notice the promise of life attached to obedience, pointing ultimately to the life given through faithfulness to the Word.

verses.text: Bind them on your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart.
verses.comment: Physical reminders of God's commands point forward to the spiritual writing of God's law upon the heart, where the new covenant fulfills the old (cf. Jer. 31:33; Heb. 10:16).

verses.text: Say to wisdom, 'You are my sister,' and call understanding your close friend,
verses.comment: The intimacy of spiritual wisdom is compared with family ties, showing the believer's relationship with divine instruction is to be daily and affectionate.

verses.text: so that they may keep you from the adulterous woman, from the foreign woman with her smooth words.
verses.comment: God's wisdom provides protection from seductive temptations. Adultery becomes a symbol of spiritual unfaithfulness, a theme found throughout Scripture (cf. Jas. 4:4).

verses.text: For at the window of my house, I looked out through my lattice,
verses.comment: The frame shifts to an eyewitness account, setting up a lesson observed from experience. Wisdom here is also portrayed as an observer.

verses.text: and I saw among the simple, I noticed among the youths, a young man lacking judgment,
verses.comment: The youth represents spiritual inexperience. Notice the need for formation and sound instruction in moral judgment.

verses.text: passing along the street near her corner, taking the road to her house
verses.comment: Deliberately placing oneself near temptation invites sin; wisdom teaches avoidance rather than confrontation.

verses.text: in the twilight, in the evening, at the time of night and darkness.
verses.comment: Sin loves the cover of darkness. Spiritual darkness often symbolizes ignorance and sin—contrasted by the light of Christ (John 8:12).

verses.text: Then a woman came to meet him, dressed like a prostitute and with cunning intent.
verses.comment: The description highlights outward temptation and inward deceit. The wise are counseled to discern the heart, not only appearances.

verses.text: She is loud and rebellious; her feet do not stay at home.
verses.comment: Restlessness and lack of peace mark those who pursue sin. Compare to the rest and stability promised to those who follow God's order.

verses.text: Now in the streets, now in the squares, she lurks at every corner.
verses.comment: The pervasiveness of temptation; wisdom counsels alertness and avoidance.

verses.text: She grabs him and kisses him, and with a bold face she says to him,
verses.comment: The seductress is portrayed as aggressive, not merely passive; this underlines the force with which sin can allure the unguarded heart.

verses.text: "I had to offer fellowship offerings; today I have paid my vows.
verses.comment: Here, religious language cloaks sinful intent. This echoes the spiritual danger of hypocrisy and outward piety apart from conversion of heart.

verses.text: So I came out to meet you, to seek you eagerly, and I have found you.
verses.comment: Eagerness in pursuing sin is contrasted with God’s call to eagerly seek wisdom and virtue. Also a reminder of the misleading feel of flattery.

verses.text: I have spread my couch with coverings, colored linens from Egyptian thread;
verses.comment: The imagery of rich coverings calls to mind the sensual nature of the temptation. Egyptian linens indicate worldliness and luxury, which often accompany sin.

verses.text: I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
verses.comment: The luxuries and perfumes recall images of both seduction and, by contrast, the worthy offering of incense in worship. The senses are easily misled without spiritual wisdom.

verses.text: "Come, let us drink deeply of love until morning; let us delight ourselves with passionate embraces.
verses.comment: False love counterfeits genuine love, which is pure and reserved for the covenant of marriage. This serves as a warning to pursue authentic love ordained by God.

verses.text: For my husband is not at home; he has gone on a long journey.
verses.comment: Here we see the secrecy of sin. The absence of rightful authority encourages sinful actions, a pattern showing how accountability helps the life of virtue.

verses.text: He took a bag of money with him; he will not come home until the full moon."
verses.comment: Sin attempts to justify itself by secrecy and timing. The reference to the 'full moon' may imply cyclical, recurring temptations; vigilance is always needed.

verses.text: With much persuasive speech she entices him; with her smooth talk she draws him in.
verses.comment: The repeated warnings about seductive speech highlight the need for spiritual fortitude and obedience to wise counsel.

verses.text: All at once he follows her, like an ox going to the slaughter, like a stag caught in a trap,
verses.comment: The imagery is stark—sin leads step by step to destruction. The idea of being led ‘like an ox’ points to the need for spiritual discernment and intentional formation.

verses.text: until an arrow pierces his liver; as a bird rushes into a snare—he does not know it will cost him his life.
verses.comment: This is a warning about the deadly consequences of spiritual adultery. The deadliness echoes Christ's call to radical avoidance of temptation (Matt. 5:29-30).

verses.text: Now therefore, my sons, listen to me, and pay attention to the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: The call to 'listen' mirrors the call of Christ to hear His teaching. True discipleship is attentive and receptive.

verses.text: Do not let your heart turn aside to her ways; do not stray into her paths.
verses.comment: It’s not only about avoiding acts, but keeping the heart—echoes of Jesus' call to inner purity (Matt. 5:27-28).

verses.text: For she has cast down many wounded; numerous are all her slain.
verses.comment: Sin's destructive power is universal. The multitude of victims shows why communal support, accountability, and the sacramental life are essential for perseverance.

verses.text: Her house is the way to the grave, going down to the chambers of death.
verses.comment: The ultimate end of spiritual unfaithfulness is death, echoing the wages of sin (Rom. 6:23). Only divine wisdom, received through faith and lived in community, leads to life.
